msgSnippet: Josh, If you use JUnit from within Eclipse, you can just right click it and run as JUnit or as an ant task. Which I found the easiest way to start with

Josh,

If you use JUnit from within Eclipse, you can just right click it and "run
as JUnit" or as an ant task. Which I found the easiest way to start with
JUnit, and if I can do it, you can too.
Hope this helps.
-Kamal.


-----Original Message-----
From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Josh
McDonald
Sent: Monday, July 10, 2006 5:37 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Junit 4 noob Q.

I'm sure this is a stupid question, but I've been searching for hours and
can't seem to find any help whatsoever. How am I supposed to run the tests?
The cookbook mentions:

org.junit.runner.TextListener.run

Which of course doesn't exist in the .jar file. What am I missing here?

-Josh
-- 

Whoa, whoa. A fat, sarcastic Star Trek fan. You must be a devil with the
ladies.

Gee, I hate to let you down Casanova, but uh, no receipt, no return.
